Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Foundations for Learning, Verifying, and Applying Model Simplification Rules

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop feature-based simplification of computer-aided-design models, specifically to accelerate and automate downstream finite-element-analysis. In particular, the research will create algorithmic foundations for learning conservative feature suppression rules from demonstrations performed by human experts. The effect of simplification on simulation accuracy will be formally characterized and this understanding will be used to create robust algorithms for feature suppression within computer-aided design models. Research findings will be integrated into graduate and undergraduate curriculum. The research will ultimately lead to a framework to automatically learn, validate, and apply context dependent model simplification rules that can be audited by human experts, and deployed to automate the model simplification task.

If successful, the research will significantly speed up model simplification, and enhance the automated use of engineering analysis tools in the design process. Potential applications include design of heat exchangers, aircraft structures, and semi-conductor equipment. The planned research and education integration activities and outreach activities will familiarize graduate, undergraduate, and high school students with the use of model simplification technologies in challenging engineering design projects. This project will also increase awareness among practicing engineers about the potential usage of automated model simplification in complex engineering design projects. Students working on this project will also participate in Badger Camp and Engineering Expo events at the University of Wisconsin campus and Maryland Day at the University of Maryland to enhance the public understanding of the science and technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three dimensional computer models are widely used in mechanical engineering design applications.  Mechanical parts need to bear loads and conduct heat.  Designing complex mechanical parts requires sophisticated simulation tools to evaluate parts.   For example, finite-element-analysis is a popular simulation tool to determine if a part can withstand the applied load or not.  The objective of this project was to develop feature-based simplification of computer-aided-design models, specifically to accelerate and automate downstream finite-element-analysis. This work created algorithmic foundations for learning conservative feature suppression rules from demonstrations performed by human experts. The effect of simplification on simulation accuracy is characterized and this understanding is used to create robust algorithms for feature suppression within computer-aided design models.  The approach developed as a part of this effort significantly speeds up model simplification, and enhances the automated use of engineering analysis tools in the design process. Potential applications include design of heat exchangers, aircraft structures, and semi-conductor equipment. Research findings were integrated into graduate and undergraduate curriculum and familiarized graduate and undergraduate students with the use of model simplification technologies in challenging engineering design projects. This project also increased awareness among practicing engineers about the potential usage of automated model simplification in complex engineering design projects.

Model simplification methods developed as a part of this work are also useful in augmented and virtual reality based training environments.  Augmented and virtual reality environments can be used in the following ways to improve manufacturing and service operations. First, experienced process engineers can perform demonstrations of manufacturing and service operations using virtual reality. These demonstrations can be used to automatically generate high quality multi-media training instructions. These instructions can be automatically updated to incorporate design changes in the products and therefore can be kept up-to-date as the product is upgraded. This method of generating instructions can significantly reduce the time needed to generate high quality training instructions. Second, operators can train in the virtual environments to learn how to perform complex assembly or service operations. Third, augmented reality can be used during the actual operation phase to provide assistance to the operators and monitor them to make sure that they do not make errors. This can significantly reduce the probability of making errors during execution.  Models with large number of features make it difficult to perform physics based simulation in real-time in virtual environments. Moreover, certain features might cause information overload for the user and hence the learning can be improved by suppressing these features. Model simplification methods developed as a part of this project were also used to identify and suppress geometric features on complex parts in the virtual environments.
